description: From earlier rightuous, rightwose, rightwos, rightwise, from Middle English rightwise, rightwis, from Old English rihtwīs (“righteous, just”), corresponding to right +‎ -wise (with assimilation of second element to -ous), or to right +‎ wise (“way, manner”). Cognate with Scots richtwis (“righteous”), Old High German rehtwīsic (“righteous, just”), Icelandic réttvíss (“righteous, just”). Compare also thefteous, mighteous.

adjectives.description: righteous (comparative more righteous, superlative most righteous)

entries.meaning: Moral and virtuous, to the point of sanctimony.
examples: Human beings should take a righteous path, and so should art. We should promote kindness and beauty through art.
He sold me a bulging paper sack full of Cambodian Red for two dolla' MPC. A strange experience, copping from a kid, but it was righteous weed.

verbs.description: righteous (third-person singular simple present righteouses, present participle righteousing, simple past and past participle righteoused)

entries.meaning: To make righteous; specifically, to justify religiously, to absolve from sin.
examples: Thus for the purposes of being ‘righteoused’, the Law was irrelevant; yet Paul could not bear to see all the Law disappear.
